conclusion: Two particles, A and B, start from rest at the same time and place, moving in the same direction.
Their motion is described by a velocity-time graph, and the task is to find the ratio of their acceleration magnitudes during deceleration phases.
In a v-t graph, the slope of the line gives the acceleration.
Positive slope indicates acceleration, negative slope indicates deceleration.
Both particles start from rest, so initial velocities are zero.
Particle A has a positive slope initially and then a negative slope.
Particle B starts with a positive slope and then has a negative slope.
Focus on deceleration phases to find the ratio of acceleration magnitudes.
Particle A accelerates to \(2v_0\) at \(t_0\) and decelerates to zero at \(2t_0\).
Particle B accelerates to \(v_0\) at \(4t_0\) and decelerates to zero at \(6t_0\).
Deceleration for particle A: change in velocity is \(-2v_0\), time is \(t_0\).
Deceleration for particle B: change in velocity is \(-v_0\), time is \(2t_0\).
